column4: Hi! is there a way to force Ubunut to have normal users and one superuser who can sudo?
thats how it normally works.
the first user you make is the sudo-able user. rest are normal nosudo users
Well, actually no; I tried sud-ing from a terminal with a normal user, and I can't do it;
any users after the 1st shouldent be able to sudo.
But sudo is precisely to say "It's a normal session, but now it's root for a few minutes at the keyboard, please allow me do power stuff"!
only the first added user has rights to run 'sudo' , any user added after that cant normally do any sudo things.
Can't i change that? I had the feeling some other distribs allow this.... Like in "sudo -u username" (that actually doesn't do anything in Ubuntu)?
you just asked how to make sure the other users could NOT do sudo.. if you want tthem to be able to sudo. you need to enable that feature for them. i dont rember how. :)
Is there a channel dedicated to accounts management and all this kind of thingS?
i would say read up on sudo - thers dosens of pages that discuss its ins and outs and configuration.
I'm doing this right as we speak.... I think I start to find something about this!
in a terminal, you can login to a different user if you wanted to.
but it can get confusing
I found the sudo -i command, but it asked me for the user's password, not root's....
yes.. thats how it works...
there is no root password..
if you run sudo as a non-sudor user. it will proberly ask for a password. then fail.
Exactly what it does. And exactly what I don't find logical
the fact that it would fail 'befor' it asked for the password - would be considered a security issue.
perhaps this way - the 'hackor' that may be trying to break in.. dosent know if why it failed.. bad password.. or invalid user.
especially if what you want to do is X....
with sudo you can setup where specific users can do specific Root-ish type tasks also..  once ya learn how sudo works.
exactly
